comments.commentBody: Treatment of the Jets as 2nd class citizens continues on Mike'd Up as Francesa runs a laundry list of breaks for the Jets before giving them credit for winning the game after San Diego "let them hang around" -

I'm sure I'll post more in another blog later, but for all the whiners (including that ridiculous post by Lynda) let's not forget the two fumbles that the Jets caused that did not bounce their way... either of them could have iced the game earlier... OR the earlier fumble that was overruled on replay --- even though it certainly seemed to me and Phil Simms (before he supposedly got an explanation explaining otherwise) like a fumble! Breaks work both ways -- the Jets could have easily have forced 5 turnovers --- and tend to even out.

For years, Sen. Enzi has stood front and center forever against efforts to regulate health insurers.  Now he says just give me a chance to regulate them and you'll see how good for all of us I can be.  When Sen. Enzi  tells us just give him a chance and he will show you there are huge amounts of water and oil beneath the Nevada desert, give him your money and tell us how it turned out.  In the meantime, support the people in Congress who are serious about health care reform.  Sen. Enzi is not.

The health care bill was supposed to be out of the Senate by the Congressional summer recess in August. Instead the Democrats have bickered among themselves, each promoting their own interests, rather than passing a bill fair to the whole US. The process has been delayed for months. Now, there is a possibility that a healthcare bill will not be passed. How will they blame their inaction on the Republicans?

Does Enzi realize that these folks who have no coverage now end up ultimately getting treated in the hospital and guess who pays for their care? WE DO!!!!!

If anything, extending coverage via Medicaid will reduce cost shifting by reducing the total amount of uncompensated care, even if Medicaid pays rates that are somewhat below costs. Right now the uninsured are paying rates that are really below costs - they are ZERO.
None of the people opposed to the Senate bill offer any analysis WHY any major provision of the bill clearly will not do what its sponsors say it will do.

It's OK Trillian as long as someone else pays yours.

Look, let's be frank about it, the healthcare plan is redistribution plain and simple. In other words, many people like Kris will wind up paying their own premiums as well as those for a stranger.

This stuff about most people who already have insurance benefiting is hogwash.

Now, compassion dictates that the better off help the worse off. But there have to be limits otherwise the better off essentially become slaves to the government.

With aggregate taxes already at around 50% of income for many, aren't we already close to the limit? Just how far do you think we should go: 70%, 80%, 90%?

At some point, this just has to stop or the economically highly productive will go on strike, a slowdown, or just leave the country.

An honest administration would admit healthcare is about redistribution and not cost saving. It would pay for the new entitlement by cutting back on existing spending, not imposing a whole new tax regime. It would have true bipartisanship meaning no sweetheart deals for unions and genuine malpractice reform among other things.

This article has it radically backwards. The reason many liberals in Massachusetts like me may not vote Democratic is because we are very angry about the Senate faux health care reform bill and about Obama's secret sweetheart deals with the medical industry and see the House bill as the only legitimate reform bill. We want single payer and can put up with a  public option. But we already have Romneycare in MA, and we know that it has no future except as welfare for the big private insurance oligopolies and big pharma. The fatally flawed WH-Senate health care bill needs to be mainly replaced by the House bill, with a public option passed later by reconciliation in the Senate. And the Senate bill's deceitful and misnamed "Cadillac" tax that was originally proposed by McCain must be rejected. Most liberals in MA are also fed up with Obama's coddling of Wall Street and his endless sugar-coated rhetoric that has almost nothing to do with his actions. We want to say No to the crypto-conservative WH and Senate. Pelosi and the House must stand firm and refuse to be stampeded or tricked into supporting the WH-Senate fake health care "reform" bill, which represents one step forward and two steps back. Whatever the exact outcome of the election, the lesson Obama and the Senate leadership need to learn from it is "Don't try to trick and ignore your base."

We are witnessing the demise of democracy as the Democrats make a mockery of the the rule of law with their outright bribes to unions and the buying of votes from people like Nelson and Landrieu.
It is absolutely shameful!

20 million WORKING Americans are uninsured--equivalent to the population of Australia. In the wise words of Otto von Bismarck: The greatest burden for the working class is the uncertainty of life. They can never be certain that they will have a job, or that they will have health and the ability to work. We cannot protect a man from all sickness and misfortune. But it is our obligation, as a society, to provide assistance when he encounters these difficulties. A rich society must care for the poor"...It's certainly worth noting that Herr von Bismarck was by all accounts, a crotchety, tax-averse, right wing aristocrat. Of course, he was shrewd politician, as well,--but the Germans, and residents of most of the rest of the developed, industrial world (with the exception of the US) owe him for setting the foundations for universal health care. American Republicans would do us all a favor by following his advice. Universal health care is not a political question, but a moral one.

The "back-up plan" for Democrats should be simple, if they'd just read the tea leaves (and every other reflection of voter sentiment): quit tinkering with this abomination of a compromised-to-death bill and START OVER.

It should surprise no one that the " deep thinkers" here can't see the forest for the trees.

Article talks about the different underhanded ways that this administration can use to CIRCUMVENT the will of the VAST majority of Americans who do not want this.

Obama clearly knows this as do these simpletons who's unwavering support for all things obama makes them spew tired old rhetoric about " how much we NEED gov. run healthcare" .

Obama and the few remaining non-thinkers on the left are about to get a real hard spanking from the AMERICAN PEOPLE.

Not Repubs , not Independents and not Democrats. It's EVERYONE. Yet you few , like your simple president , ignore the will of the people to support your mindless far left "ideas" .

And # 1 Kris ? I applaud you on your hard EARNED healthcare. # 14 Trillion also applauds you - and would now like you to pay for his healthcare as well.

The ONE good thing to come out of obama's presidency - the complete and total destruction of the liberal movement in this country. Done.

In the long run , it was well worth electing him for this very reason.

Here on the ground, I have had one recent experience, that deals with the topic, and might interest you. I was given a prescription for an eighth of an ounce of Bacitracin ointment. It cost forty dollars, when I filled it at my drugstore. That same ointment, in an equivalent dosage, cost forty cents, had it been purchased over the counter. Both, had exactly the same ingredients, with the only difference being, that the prescription tube, had the word, STERILE, imprinted on the outside. Now, is there something wrong with this picture, or am I missing something?!
Only thing missing from this discussion?  I'm still waiting for Judy Batista to come in and make here obligatory "It's only a matter of time before Favre implodes" threads/posts ....

Dr. Baumol is right, we can afford healthcare. Studies show the cost to provide insurance for 45 million americans would be 120 billion dollars. If washington simply paid for the insurance, the insurance pool would see far more healthy people enter than sick (who get care in emergency rooms which the feds reimburse about 60 billion now). The net cost would be nowhere near the cost of bureaucracies, entitlement programs, taxes, cost-shifting plans that rocket scientists could not figure out, and would result in the risk pool becoming, well, healthier. This alone would drive prices down. Throw in tort reform, pharmacy initiatives, outcomes based medicine and junk fee-for-service pricing, and american citizens would be able to see some value from the insurance system.

Like the quintet, the musicians we already have can be paid properly and the rate of price increase will slow by adding the uninsured to the equation. That won't take thousands of pages of legislation or czars, and won't fatten lobbyist and special interest groups pockets. There are plenty of ways to slow the cost increase, changing the quintet to a symphony orchestra is not one of them.

Walt Bennett,

Thanks for the honesty. Funny how many of the negative, macho pro-Jets comments come from people who don't bother to leave their last names. To those first name types, I don't believe that I am actually a sore loser; I've been a Chargers fan far too long to be that! (To those of you unfamiliar with our franchise history, we have never won a Super Bowl, have only attended one, and typically choke in clutch moments like this one. We're very accustomed to losing.) In fact, I'm pretty sure I admitted in my earlier comment that my team truly did not deserve to win that football game. And if you'd ever watched a football game with me you'd know that I always admit it when the other team gives us a good, old-fashioned you-know-what kicking. (The Niners did in Superbowl 29; the Jets didn't tonight.) So feel free to criticize my analysis of the game, but don't write it off as sour grapes -- that's unsportmanslike conduct on your part, not too different from kicking a challenge flag.

And I will admit that Walt and other commenters have a point, and sometimes a good team shows its greatness not with flash but simply by making other teams look bad. That may or may not be true of the Jets -- I guess we'll see next week. But you all have to admit: you simply can't "force" some of the mistakes made by the Chargers team today. Nate Kaeding's failures (especially when compared to his nearly flawless record) were ours alone, and those unearned points could be said to have caused your win. I realize that you can never blame a loss entirely on any one or two missed plays, and that if we had made those field goals, you might have responded to them. But you can't deny that they played a huge (and perhaps determining) role in your win.

So congratulations, Jets fans. Enjoy tonight's glory. But as a final note I'll echo my mom -- a New Jersey born San Diegan, with ties to both teams -- and say that based on the way they played tonight, neither team looked like one who would (or should) end up playing in the Super Bowl. So take this week to figure out how to get your offense into the red zone often and early, without relying on penalties and interceptions for field position. And maybe, just maybe you'll make the Colts look as bad as the Chargers.

I might kind of enjoy that, too. Did anyone count the number of times Peyton Manning appeared in commercials today? It's getting to be a bit much.

We spend roughly twice as much per capita as the average developed country. We are the only country with for profit insurance companies, the only country where specialists routinely have seven figure incomes, the only country with these absurd tort laws, etc. If our politicians wouldn't fold to the pressure of the special interests, we could certainly lower our costs dramatically. Then we might face the same cost increase pressures that other countries face, but we would be starting from a much reduced per capita cost.

I also suspect that economic self-interest is keeping the doctors from turning over much of what they do to physician's assistants, who could be supported by expert decision tree software that utilized best practice data.
Survival of the fittest society is not an advancement of civilization.

I like the people who say democrats cut deals....news flash....they had to. They have 58 senators and for the great democracy we need 60. Since Republicans hate everything that isnt done for profit we werent going to get 1 of there votes. We hear all about how the republicans say there will be death panels well the truth is if republicans had there way we would never had medicare. You want to see a real death panel tell an elderly person to go try and find private insurance. I work in the health care system for the cleveland clinic and it makes me sick to see the GOP smiling talking about how they succeeded in killing health care in 1994. Since that time working middleclass people have seen there rates rise and there deductibles and co-pays get higher. So I just want to say to those GOP members bragging about killing health care reform in 1994 congrats in that time 720,000 Americans have died from lack of insurance "45,000" americans die every year from lack of recieving proper medical attention. You know i wonder what those who fight getting everyone quality health care would say if Jesus were on earth cause in the bible they cast the sick aside to an island and Jesus went to them. To quote jesus "how you treat the least of my people the poor, THE SICK and the imprisoned is how you treat me" of course if Jesus said that today Shaun, Rush and Glenn would say watch out for this socialist.
If obama back doors this health plan he'll leave the wh the same way.

There are two major mistaken statements by the author of this article. First, the health care bill will not be "far reaching health care legislation." Pelosi and House Democrats have indicated they will surrender on most of the differences with the Senate bill, resulting in a relatively weak House bill being diluted to a weaker overall bill.

Second, most people seem to be predicting there will be no health care bill if Brown wins the Senate election Tuesday. This is an insult to the intelligence of most people and a scare tactic being used by Democrats to try to sway some voters in Massachusetts.

A health care bill could be still be passed, but Obama and the vast majority of Democrats would have to compromise with a few Republicans, which they do not want to do at this stage. Obama seems desperate to have a health care bill passed before his state of the union speech, so he can have something to brag about. However, getting health care right should be considered more important than boosting the ego of the president.

As Dr. Bellamy notes, Massachusetts citizens have learned the hard way how expensive "reform" can be when the people who actually know how much things cost are excluded from the process. The resulting experiment is turning out to prove that without evidence based clinical practice guidelines, without tort reform, without competition based on price, outcomes and evidence, nobody can figure out how to get value from the system.

The result is lots of money wasted and we've got a president hell-bent on replicating this on a national scale, mortgaging our childrens future and driving us deeper into debt. This is another reason why the folks of the Bay State will likely turn to Scott Brown. The people understand the pain of doing the right thing the wrong way. The last thing the senate needs is another rubber-stamp for this legislation. It might be time to admit that the best thing is to go back to the drawing boards, ask doctors (not the AMA) and patients what they really NEED (not want) and cut out the backroom deals and secrecy.

The vitriol against Republicans is stunning.  The media has sold the public an image of Republicans that is actually more a refection of Democrats - self serving and self indulgent.  To consider accountability and transparency traits of the Democrats is nothing ut laughable.  For this President to ride so high on the platform of change and to not only not change but to be more corrupt than any Republican could ever be, to be willing to steal so openly from the middle class for his own ideological gains is stunning in its deception.  I hope the country wakes up and realizes the Democrat fear of Republicans is only a fear based on stereotype that have little to do with reality.  Get a grip and take a look at what is going on, America.

I am of the opinion that the Republicans will do anything in their power
to kill Obama's health care plan.

Quite frankly the Republicans are more
concerned with winning back the Congress and the presidency than they
are with health care.

The Republicans couldn't give two hoots about health care reform in this country.
Whether or not millions go without health insurance is a non issue for them.

What we have here is an "obstructionist" group enjoying their cadillac health insurance plans, but denying it to the people who need it the most.

If the Republicans have their way, millions of American citizens will not have health insurance;and may die or become bankrupt.

The Republican party has banded together to outfox Obama.
If given the chance they will abandon Americans in need of health insurance
thus perpetuating the embarrassment of being the only country in the Western World without a national health care plan.

Republican status-seeking, and self-serving obstructionist behavior
has taken precedence to the needs of the people.

Liberals are free to donate their own money any time they want to any charity they want.  However, they have no right to donate other people's money.  We like to choose our own charities.  ACORN is the government's idea of a charity.  It should not be too much to ask that we get to choose our own.
